title: New data sources, innovation trends and challenges on information retrieval in UNICEF

author: Manuel García-Herranz, Computer Science Department, Autonomous University of Madrid

segmentation: Manuel Garcia Ahrons is from UNICEF and they're doing awesome stuff so give it up for Manuel.
Hi, well first thank you for hosting us.
Be cool to be here, specially with the air conditioning.
That's cool.
So I'm highly recently hired as a research scientist in the innovation unit in UNICEF.
Here at New York.

So barely a month in UNICEF hardly qualifies me as UNICEF yet, but I'm still going to talk about what I've been able to see in this month, on how we use new sources of data and what are the innovation trends and challenges in information retrieval we're facing so.
The first thing is one can say about UNICEF is that UNICEF is big, is huge, is global, and is local.
It is present in 135 different countries.
It has more than 15,000 staff members, 88% of which are actually in the field, so it's really the centralized.
It has a pretty big budget.
But in terms of data and from our computer science point of view, which I am.
UNICEF is both a dream and a nightmare.
UNICEF uses an has access to virtually all sorts of information and data from in-house data, like the yearly surveys they conduct were talking about 12,000 households in 100 different countries.
This is a huge survey, but then we have the 135 different country officers and regional offices with local data, and then we have access to government data and other side.
We process news all sorts of different agencies an at the end.
What we have is a big picture, huge picture which is the centralized, incomplete and most of the times is just human readable so.
To go through all these stuff just by hand.
So here I propose the first challenge, which is how can we aggregate these data and give sense to that and make it automatically in a computer readable form?
So this is about information, but the information at the end has one objective which is serve the children and according to the equity agenda the hardest to reach.
But the problem here is how do we generate information from the invisible?
There?
A lot of kids there that we don't know off, so that's where the innovation unit comes in and we are thinking in new ways and technological ways of getting.

This information so when we look at information technologies developing countries, they display significantly different picture than we are using developed ones I love and I have personal interest on on Twitter experiments and Facebook experiments, but this is the case of Uganda.
Only 2% of the richest people have Facebook accounts.
Internet access is a little bit higher, 10% of the luckiest one in the biggest cities.
So it's not representative either, but phone.

Traditional phones I'm talking here about these old phones, Nokia style with the amazing capabilities of making a call and send SMS that's 40% of the people have a phone and many times 1 phone is used by many people.
So they the phones can be a true vector of chains and that's why we pay particular attention.
To this one.
So the first thing with these would you suggest for communication?
What kind of processes were already doing paper based paper that then goes in donkeys and trucks to other places?
How can we do that?
And using SMS we were able to improve child registration, family reunification in emergencies and a lot of many other different process.

I want to go a little step beyond that, and that's about crowdsourcing, so we're using SMS in programs like you report to allow people to directly communicate with their government or with UNICEF, and to UNICEF to pull information from them.
And that's Uganda data, for example, more than 200,000 you reporters already inscribed.
There are like 2 poles per week, and that provides a significant view of the country we didn't have before.
Now second challenge here.
How can we process all the information that is not related to polls, but they were just message coming coming in.
How can we automatically process that and say this is a healthy thing that needs action?
Or is educational thing that is just information and a second question is can we get any other knowledge from that?
Let's say response times?
Is that telling us something else that we are miss?
In there.
And finally, I'm going to finish with with a different project.
Alex has already talk about that, but since phones are there, we can use it not only to communicate, but we can use it to analyze.
Yes, the italics cost, and that's especially important in places in which we cannot go or we have no time to go, such as in the landslides of Uganda in 2012, so.
Challenge for the KDD community is how can we extract fast knowledge from new sources like the details to exhaust whether something bad has happened worries the people when that happened.
Where will they go?
How resilient they are socially, economically?

So I would say that the information lack of information is probably the biggest challenge we have in reaching the most invisible and that phones and simple technology can make a huge impact in giving them boys and hearing their problems when they don't have one.
And I would really appreciate any kind of input and help from a community such as that.
Thank you very much.
